qas.question: What conjecture holds that there is an infinite amount of twin primes?
Which conjecture holds that for any positive integer n, there is an infinite amount of pairs of consecutive primes differing by 2n?
Of what form is the infinite amount of primes that comprise the special cases of Schinzel's hypothesis?
What conjecture holds that there are always a minimum of 4 primes  between the squares of consecutive primes greater than 2?
What conjecture holds that there is an infinite amount of twin positives?
Which conjecture holds that for any negative integer n, there is an infinite amount of pairs of consecutive primes differing by 2n?
Of what form is the infinite amount of positives that comprise the special cases of Schinzel's hypothesis?
What conjecture holds that there are always a minimum of 1 prime between the squares of consecutive primes greater than 2?

context: A third type of conjectures concerns aspects of the distribution of primes. It is conjectured that there are infinitely many twin primes, <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><a1_3><b6_0>pairs of primes with difference 2<b6_0/><a1_3/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/> (<a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b5_0>twin prime conjecture<b5_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>). <a0_3><a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><a2_3><b7_0>Polignac's<a2_3/><a2_1/><a0_3/> conjecture<b7_0/><a2_2/><a2_0/> is a strengthening of that conjecture, it states that for every positive integer n, there are infinitely many pairs of consecutive primes that differ by 2n. It is conjectured there are infinitely many primes of the form <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><a3_3><b8_0>n2 + 1<b8_0/><a3_3/><a3_1/><a3_0/>.<a3_2/> These conjectures are special cases of the broad Schinzel's hypothesis H. <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2><a4_3><b9_0>Brocard's<a4_3/><a4_1/> conjecture<b9_0/><a4_2/><a4_0/> says that there are always at least four primes between the squares of consecutive primes greater than 2. Legendre's conjecture states that there is a prime number between n2 and (n + 1)2 for every positive integer n. It is implied by the stronger Cramér's conjecture.
